notesStmt.note: Areas of paint in the miniatures and border decoration are in poor condition, especially on first and last folios; sewing structures compromised between some gatherings
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2043, no. 109.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Library, 1937), pp. 189-191, no. 176.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript consists of a collection of various prayers to be read in conjunction with portions of the Mass, but it follows no known common set of prayers. The manuscript contains four full-page miniatures that introduce each section of prayers. These depict, respectively, the owner (a Benedictine monk with an unidentified coat-of-arms) in prayer before an altar (fol. 2v), a monstrance adored by two musical angels (fol. 26v), the Virgin and Child in glory (fol. 112v), and the Trinity (fol. 122v). The book is dated precisely to 22 September 1538 on folio 146v, and can be localized to Saint Amand, near Valenciennes. Later additions at the beginning and end of the manuscript are dated 1576 and contain the name of a later owner, Charles Fontaine, but the identity of the original owner depicted in the miniature on fol. 2v remains unknown. The later additions as-yet contain unidentified mottoes and coats-of-arms. The rubrics of several prayers indicate that indulgences would be granted upon reading. The manuscript is closely related in script, date, and localization to Lewis E 109.

msItem.title: Commendatio (added 1576), rubric: Commendatio ad Deum supplici inente de mane dicendo
msItem.explicit: …qui in trinitatie perfecta viuis et regnaris. Per omnia secula. [fol. 2r]

msItem.title: Prayers to be said before Confession, including meditations on the Passion (fols. 5r-26r), with readings from Ludolf of Saxony, Pope Urban V, and Bernard of Clairvaux, rubric: Sequuntur orationes dicende a[n]te confessionem
msItem.incipit: Per sanctorum omnium angelorum archangelorum patriacharum... [fol. 3r]

msItem.title: Prayers to be said before Mass (first folio with rubric has been removed; folio facing miniatures begins with prayer to the Holy Trinity to be said on Sundays), rubric: Dominicis diebus ad sanctam trinitatem
msItem.explicit: …tu scis et necessitatem nostram nostri. Qui viuis. [fol. 112r]

msItem.title: Prayers to the Virgin Mary, rubric: Sequuntur orationes deuote ad gloriosam Virginem Mariam. Sixtus papa eius[?] hanc sequentem orationem edidit et omnibus eam deuote dicentibus coram ymagine [hainis meae?] sole et luna dedit indulgentias XI iii annorum totiens qotiens quis legerit in statu gratia.
msItem.incipit: Ave sanctissima maria mater dei regina celi… [fol. 113r]
msItem.explicit: …et benedicte passionis tue doloris gladius pertransunt. Qui viuis et regnas deus. Per omnia secula seculorum. Amen [fol. 112r]

msItem.title: Suffrages, rubric: Sequuntur suffragia sanctorum et sanctarum. Et prima oratio ad deum patrem
msItem.incipit: Pater de celis deum. Misere nobis... [fol. 123r]
msItem.explicit: …cum patre et paradiso regnanti in perpetuum. Amen. [fol. 146v]

msItem.title: Prayer to All Saints (added 1576), rubric: Oratio ad omnes sanctos
msItem.incipit: Succurrite michi queso omnes sancti et sanctae dei... [fol. 147r]
msItem.explicit: …Presentante domino nostro Iesu Christo. Qui cum deo proximo[?] et spiritu sancto viuit et regnat deus. Per omnia secula. [fol. 148r]

msItem.title: Prayers said after Mass (incomplete; added 1576), rubric: Gratiarum actiones post missam
msItem.explicit: …et per te cepta finiat… [fol. 148v; text ends imperfectly]

supportDesc.extent: ii+149+ii; 131 x 85 mm bound to 136 x 89 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto; after fol. 45 there is a fol. 45bis; the foliation has not been corrected

layoutDesc.layout: One column of 18-21 lines, lead point ruling (barely visible); written area: 89 x 57 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Four full-page miniatures: Benedictine Monk, likely the original owner (f. 2v), Two Angels Holding a Monstrance (f. 26v), Virgin and Child in Glory, the Virgin standing on a crescent (f. 112v), Holy Trinity (Gnadenstuhl type) (f. 122v); three illuminated initials with borders, one two-thirds page miniature: IHS monogram (f. 146v); four borders with coats of arms around text pages; illuminated initials and line-fillers throughout
2rIlluminated border with inscription, CEDE VINCE D. CAROLUS FONTANUS; QU'A DIEU SERVIR
2vFull-page miniature, Benedictine Monk in prayer before Altar, unidentified coat-of-arms
26vFull-page miniature, Two music-making angels flanking a monstrance
26vIlluminated border with inscription, ECCE PANIS ANGELORUM FACTUS CIBUS VIATORUM
112vFull-page miniature, Virgin and Child in Glory, the Virgin standing on a crescent
146vLarge miniature, IHS Monogram with rebus "Je pense à toi"

binding.p: English, purple morocco with blind-tooled covers, gilt lettering on spine ("MANUSCRIPT"), silk and gilt-tooled doublures, early 19th century

origin.p: Part one was created in 1538 (fols. 3r-146v; dated 22 September, 1538 on fol. 146v); part two in 1576 (fols. 1r-2r and 147r-148v); inscription in upper border on. fol. 148v gives date 1576 (the "5" is partially erased); main text dated 22 September, 1538; additions dated 1576; 1576

history.provenance: Made at the abbey of Saint Amand, dated "1538.22. d'Septeb" on fol. 146v; name and coat of arms of Charles Fontaine in borders alongside added text (fols. 1-2, 147-148), 16th century; Henry White, London, second half of the nineteenth century; his sale, Sotheby's, London, April 21-May 2, 1902, lot 1142; T.W. Greene; sale, Sotheby's, London, July 8, 1913, lot 330; Bertram Dobell (bookseller), London (later P.J. & A.E. Dobell); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
